Sigh.  I guess I have to file yet another WebKit forms bug, against the absolutely crazy <input type=date> implementation.
Does WebKit like not have a UI team that's reviewing these changes or something?

I don't remember installing a nightly
Safari 5?
And by "works" you mean "treats it as a number-picker instead of a date-picker"?
I'm not sure if it's actually worse than just treating it as a text box, to be fair.
the guy who's messing it up is at least trying to actually implement the HTML5 forms feature
Yes, I'll give him that.
But a bad implementation is worse than no implementation.
If it's no implementation, at least you can feature-detect.
And substitute something scripted.
well, the solution to that is to put some other actual engineering resources on it
instead of simply bitching about it

it is open-source code

win
AryehGregor: didn't mean you personally

I really wouldn't object to the work not getting done.  It's not a critical feature.  But shipping broken support is poisoning the well, making it much more difficult to use the feature in browsers that do support it well (like Firefox 4, to all indications).
thanks karlcow

The only people who can stop the current work from being done are the person doing it and the people who run WebKit, so complaining to them is really the only thing anyone can do, except those people themselves.
I think Firefox does not support <input type=date> actually
Right, which is fine.
AryehGregor: agreed about shipping with the broken implementation -- it seems like it did get enabled and released prematurely

(others shipped just fine, like placeholder AFAICT)
yeah, it seems like there needs to be something to prevent similar problems from happening in the future

question: is all of the CSS3 spec. considered to be a part of HTML5?
by whom?
"part of"?
lol
perhaps i can ask this a different way
By people who know what HTML5 means, no
that's what i thought Ms2ger
Is there functionality defined in the Css3 spec which is considered to be technically outside of the HTML5 spec?
all of it
I didn't understand your question, but I'll note there are a lot of CSS3 specs
virtuelv, all of css is separate from HTML5?
i thought css3 colors were in there
In what way?
html and css are complements, but they do not overlap in any way
Canvas uses css3 colors, I guess
no, JS uses css3 colors
Ms2ger: either way, in the sense that html5 might have dependencies on css3, it would be found in the "references" section of the html5 spec
thanks
virtuelv, thanks, I wrote most of that section :)

2.5.6 - Colors: If keyword is an ASCII case-insensitive match for one of the keywords listed in the SVG color keywords section of the CSS3 Color specification, then return the simple color corresponding to that keyword.
That sounds like bgcolor parsing
f1lt3r, HTML5 normatively depends on some CSS 3 standards: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/references.html#references
However, they aren't part of HTML5, any more than any other normative references (e.g., RFC 2616).
interesting
thanks guys, much appreciated
However again, "HTML5" is often used as a buzzword to include any modern web technology.
also i'm guessing html5 defines some default css settings
if that counts

starts to think this code needs to be largely rewritten to match the spec, since it's different at a conceptual level in so many places.

(which, again, is probably what other browsers do too)
